title: Thomas Kelly (Sinn Féin politician)
text:
Thomas Kelly (13 September 1868 – 20 April 1942) was an Irish <a href="Sinn%20F%C3%A9in">Sinn Féin</a> and later <a href="Fianna%20F%C3%A1il">Fianna Fáil</a> politician. He was a book and picture dealer before entering politics. He was a founder member of Sinn Féin and was elected to <a href="Dublin%20City%20Council">Dublin City Council</a> in 1899. Kelly was arrested after the 1916 <a href="Easter%20Rising">Easter Rising</a> and sent to prison in England, and after becoming seriously ill, he was released back to Dublin.
He was elected as a <a href="Sinn%20F%C3%A9in">Sinn Féin</a> <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">MP</a> for the <a href="Dublin%20St%20Stephen%27s%20Green%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Dublin St Stephens's Green</a> constituency at the <a href="1918%20Irish%20general%20election">1918 general election</a>. In January 1919, Sinn Féin MPs refused to recognise the <a href="Parliament%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Parliament of the United Kingdom</a> and instead assembled at the <a href="Mansion%20House%2C%20Dublin">Mansion House</a> in <a href="Dublin">Dublin</a> as a revolutionary parliament called <a href="First%20D%C3%A1il">Dáil Éireann</a>.
Kelly was unanimously elected as <a href="Lord%20Mayor%20of%20Dublin">Lord Mayor of Dublin</a> while being held in <a href="HM%20Prison%20Wormwood%20Scrubs">Wormwood Scrubs prison</a> in England. Due to his imprisonment, he was unable to formally take up the position.
He was re-elected unopposed at the <a href="1921%20Irish%20elections">1921 elections</a> for the <a href="Dublin%20South%20%28D%C3%A1il%20constituency%29">Dublin South</a> constituency. He supported the <a href="Anglo-Irish%20Treaty">Anglo-Irish Treaty</a> but was too ill to attend the <a href="Anglo-Irish%20Treaty%20D%C3%A1il%20vote">Dáil vote</a>. He served as substitute <a href="Minister%20for%20Labour%20%28Ireland%29">Minister for Labour</a> from 19 March 1919 to end of October 1919. He was again re-elected at the <a href="1922%20Irish%20general%20election">1922 general election</a> as a member of Pro-Treaty Sinn Féin but did not take his seat in the Dáil.
He did not join <a href="Cumann%20na%20nGaedheal">Cumann na nGaedheal</a> along with other pro-Treaty Sinn Féin TDs in 1923, nor did he contest the <a href="1923%20Irish%20general%20election">1923 general election</a>. In 1930 he joined Fianna Fáil and was elected as a <a href="Fianna%20F%C3%A1il">Fianna Fáil</a> <a href="Teachta%20D%C3%A1la">Teachta Dála</a> (TD) at the <a href="1933%20Irish%20general%20election">1933 general election</a> for <a href="Dublin%20South%20%28D%C3%A1il%20constituency%29">Dublin South</a>. He remained a TD and councillor until his death in 1942.
